quick_answer.what: Mount Tambora is an active stratovolcano on Sumbawa Island in Indonesia, rising to 2,850 m (9,350 ft). It forms the entire 60-km-wide Sanggar Peninsula.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted July 1967 (VEI 0). The 6-km-wide, 1,250-m-deep summit caldera is a testament to the catastrophic 1815 eruption.
quick_answer.famous_for: The April 1815 VEI 7 eruption — the largest and deadliest volcanic eruption in recorded history. An estimated 60,000–92,000 people died, and the eruption caused the Year Without a Summer in 1816.
quick_answer.danger_level: Moderate — currently in long repose. A repeat VEI 7 eruption is extremely unlikely on human timescales but would be a global catastrophe.

overview.content: Mount Tambora (Indonesian: Gunung Tambora) is an active stratovolcano on the northern coast of Sumbawa Island in the Lesser Sunda Islands of Indonesia, currently rising to 2,850 m (9,350 ft) above sea level. It is the site of the largest volcanic eruption in recorded human history: the cataclysmic VEI 7 eruption of April 10, 1815, which ejected an estimated 150 km³ or more of tephra, killed approximately 60,000–92,000 people through direct volcanic effects and subsequent famine, and caused the global ‘Year Without a Summer’ in 1816 — the most severe climate perturbation of the 19th century. Before 1815, Tambora stood approximately 4,300 m (14,100 ft) tall — one of the highest peaks in the Indonesian archipelago. The eruption removed roughly 1,450 m from the summit and created a caldera 6 km wide and 1,250 m deep, transforming the volcano’s profile from a towering cone to a truncated hulk. The massive Tambora stratovolcano forms the entire 60-km-wide Sanggar Peninsula on northern Sumbawa, an edifice of enormous volume built primarily from trachybasaltic to trachyandesitic lavas and pyroclastic deposits. Tambora sits on the Sunda Volcanic Arc, generated by the subduction of the Indo-Australian Plate beneath the Eurasian Plate. With only 7 confirmed eruptions spanning roughly 6,000 years, Tambora erupts infrequently — but when it does, the consequences can be global. The 1815 eruption ranks alongside the Minoan eruption of Santorini (~1610 BCE) as one of only a few confirmed VEI 7 events in the Holocene, and its human toll — both from direct casualties and from the worldwide agricultural catastrophe that followed — makes it arguably the most consequential volcanic event in modern history. Minor lava dome growth and steam emissions occurred within the caldera in the 19th and 20th centuries, with the most recent activity recorded in 1967, but Tambora has been in a state of quiet repose for over half a century.

geology_and_formation.content: Tambora is a massive stratovolcano whose edifice, encompassing the entire 60-km-wide Sanggar Peninsula, represents one of the largest volcanic structures in Indonesia. The volcano grew to approximately 4,300 m elevation before forming an initial caldera more than 43,000 years ago. Late Pleistocene lava flows largely filled this early caldera, after which activity shifted to dominantly explosive eruptions during the early Holocene. The volcano’s tectonic setting on the Sunda Volcanic Arc — where the Indo-Australian Plate subducts beneath the Eurasian Plate at approximately 6–7 cm per year — is shared with some of the world’s most famous volcanoes, including Krakatau, Merapi, and Agung. However, Tambora’s magma composition is somewhat unusual for the arc: its lavas are dominantly trachybasaltic to trachyandesitic, enriched in alkali elements compared to the more typical calc-alkaline andesites found at most Sunda Arc volcanoes. This alkalic character may reflect the influence of the underlying continental crust (greater than 25 km thick beneath Sumbawa) on magma evolution, or differences in the subduction zone geometry in the eastern Sunda Arc. The pre-1815 edifice was a steep-sided cone built through tens of thousands of years of alternating effusive and explosive activity. The 1815 caldera — 6 km in diameter and approximately 1,250 m deep — is one of the largest volcanic craters on Earth, comparable in scale to the calderas of Santorini and Krakatau. Within the caldera, minor lava domes and flows extruded during the 19th and 20th centuries represent the initial stages of post-catastrophic rebuilding.

eruption_history_overview.content: Tambora’s confirmed eruption record is remarkably sparse for such a consequential volcano: only 7 eruptions are documented, spanning from approximately 3910 BCE to 1967. This low frequency reflects Tambora’s character as a volcano that stores energy over long repose intervals before releasing it in catastrophically powerful events. Three of the seven eruptions lack assigned VEI values (the prehistoric events at ~3910 BCE, ~3050 BCE, and ~740 CE), while the historical record is dominated by the colossal 1815 eruption (VEI 7) and three minor post-caldera events (1819, 1880, and 1967, all VEI 0–2). The eruption frequency and pattern suggest that Tambora operates on a fundamentally different timescale than prolific volcanoes like Etna or Cotopaxi. Rather than frequent, moderate eruptions, Tambora appears to accumulate large volumes of magma over centuries to millennia before producing rare but catastrophically large eruptions. The 1815 event, which ejected more than 150 km³ of tephra, represents one of the largest known eruptions in the Holocene epoch.

subsections.title: The 1815 Eruption — The Largest Eruption in Recorded History
subsections.content: The eruption of Mount Tambora in April 1815 stands as the largest confirmed volcanic eruption in recorded human history, a VEI 7 event that exceeded any other eruption documented by contemporaneous witnesses. The eruption unfolded in two principal phases and produced consequences that rippled across the entire globe for years afterward. Precursory activity began in 1812, when Tambora entered a period of increased rumbling and steam emission after centuries of apparent dormancy. On April 5, 1815, a major explosive phase began with a thunderous eruption heard over 1,400 km away in Sumatra — so distant that the governor of Java initially believed it to be cannon fire from a ship in distress and dispatched military vessels to investigate. The climactic paroxysm occurred on the evening of April 10, 1815, and continued through April 11. The eruption column is estimated to have reached 43 km (27 mi) into the stratosphere. Pyroclastic flows — incandescent avalanches of superheated gas, ash, and rock traveling at hundreds of kilometers per hour — swept down all flanks of the volcano, reaching the sea on every side of the Sanggar Peninsula. These flows obliterated everything in their path, including the Kingdom of Tambora (a local sultanate of approximately 10,000 people on the peninsula’s north coast) which was completely destroyed and buried. The eruption ejected an estimated 150 km³ or more of tephra (approximately 41 km³ dense-rock equivalent), removed roughly 1,450 m from the summit, and created the 6-km-wide, 1,250-m-deep summit caldera. Tephra fall was reported across an area of roughly 500,000 km². On Lombok, 200 km to the west, tephra accumulations reached over 60 cm. The eruption was heard as far away as Sumatra (2,600 km). The direct death toll from pyroclastic flows, tephra fall, and tsunamis is estimated at approximately 12,000 people. However, the indirect death toll from famine and disease was catastrophically higher. Crop destruction across Sumbawa, Lombok, and eastern Java led to an estimated 49,000–80,000 additional deaths, bringing the total to approximately 60,000–92,000 — the deadliest volcanic eruption in recorded history.

subsections.title: The ‘Year Without a Summer’ (1816) — Global Climate Catastrophe
subsections.content:
The most far-reaching consequence of the 1815 eruption was its profound effect on global climate. The eruption injected an estimated 60 million tonnes of sulfur dioxide into the stratosphere, where it formed a persistent veil of sulfate aerosols that reflected incoming solar radiation and cooled the planet. Global average temperatures dropped by approximately 0.4–0.7°C, and 1816 became known as the ‘Year Without a Summer.’

In Europe, the summer of 1816 was the coldest on record, with persistent cold, rain, and snow in June and July. Crop failures led to widespread famine — the last great subsistence crisis in European history. Food riots broke out in France, Switzerland, and Germany. In Ireland, the cold wet summer devastated the potato crop and contributed to a typhus epidemic killing approximately 65,000 people. In North America, New England experienced frost in every month of 1816, with snow in June across Vermont and upstate New York.

The climate disruption had cascading cultural consequences. The cold summer of 1816 in Switzerland confined Mary Shelley, Percy Shelley, and Lord Byron indoors at Lake Geneva, leading to the writing competition that produced ‘Frankenstein.’ The lurid sunsets produced by stratospheric aerosols inspired J.M.W. Turner’s paintings. Agricultural failures accelerated westward migration in the United States. The connection between Tambora’s eruption and the 1816 climate anomaly was not scientifically established until the 20th century.

subsections.title: Post-1815 Activity — Caldera Rebuilding
subsections.content: Following the 1815 eruption, Tambora entered a period of intermittent, low-level activity. A VEI 2 eruption in August 1819 produced minor explosive activity from the caldera floor. In 1880, a small eruption at the Doro Afi Toi vent in the southwestern caldera produced a lava dome. The most recent eruption occurred on July 2, 1967 — a VEI 0 event consisting of steam emissions from the northeastern caldera floor. Since 1967, Tambora has been in fumarolic repose. The caldera floor hosts a small seasonal lake, minor fumarolic fields, and remnants of 19th-century lava domes.

current_status_and_monitoring.content:
Mount Tambora is classified as an active volcano in a long repose, with no confirmed eruptive activity since the minor 1967 event. The volcano is monitored by Indonesia’s PVMBG (Center for Volcanology and Geological Hazard Mitigation). Tambora’s current alert level is Normal (Level I), the lowest on the Indonesian four-tier scale.

The caldera interior shows persistent but low-level signs of ongoing volcanic activity, including fumarolic emissions and warm ground temperatures near the 19th-century lava domes. Seismic monitoring detects occasional volcanic earthquakes beneath the edifice, consistent with a still-active magmatic system at depth. However, none of the current indicators suggest that a significant eruption is imminent.

The long-term outlook is uncertain. Volcanoes that produce VEI 7 eruptions typically require thousands to tens of thousands of years to reaccumulate sufficient magma for a repeat event. Only approximately 210 years have passed since 1815. Smaller eruptions (VEI 2–3) involving lava dome growth on the caldera floor are considered the most plausible near-term scenario.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content:
Tambora’s primary hazard profile is defined by the potential for future explosive eruptions generating pyroclastic flows, tephra fall, and lahars, though the probability of a repeat VEI 7 event in any given century is very low. More plausible near-term scenarios include phreatic explosions within the caldera, small explosive eruptions (VEI 2–3) with ashfall, and lava dome growth.

The Sanggar Peninsula and surrounding Sumbawa lowlands have a population of approximately 100,000. Population density is considerably lower than at many other Indonesian volcanic centers. However, in the extremely unlikely event of a repeat VEI 7 eruption, the consequences would be global. Pyroclastic flows would devastate the entire peninsula. The climatic impact — comparable to the ‘Year Without a Summer’ — would disrupt global agriculture in a world far more interconnected and populated than in 1815. The contrast between local low-probability threat and global high-consequence potential makes Tambora an important case study in catastrophic volcanic risk assessment.

geography_and_physical_description.content:
Mount Tambora dominates the geography of Sumbawa Island, forming the entire 60-km-wide Sanggar Peninsula that protrudes northward into the Flores Sea. The current summit elevation of 2,850 m (9,350 ft) belies its massive footprint. The summit caldera, approximately 6 km in diameter and 1,250 m deep, is one of the most dramatic volcanic landforms in Indonesia — a vast, steep-walled amphitheater containing a small seasonal lake and remnants of post-1815 lava domes.

The outer slopes descend through dense tropical forest at intermediate elevations to agricultural lowlands and coastal villages near sea level. Deep ravines radiate from the upper slopes, channeling seasonal water runoff and volcanic debris flows. The volcano’s flanks are draped in tropical vegetation that has recolonized since the 1815 destruction — a testament to the resilience of tropical ecosystems, though some areas remain conspicuously bare after two centuries.

Sumbawa Island is part of the Lesser Sunda Island chain (Nusa Tenggara), considerably less developed and populated than Java to the west, with the towns of Bima and Dompu serving as regional centers.

climate_and_global_impact.content: The 1815 eruption produced the most significant volcanic climate perturbation in recorded history. The injection of approximately 60 million tonnes of sulfur dioxide into the stratosphere created a global aerosol veil reducing solar radiation by 1–2%, lowering global temperatures by 0.4–0.7°C and triggering the ‘Year Without a Summer’ in 1816. The Northern Hemisphere was most severely affected, with summer temperatures in Western Europe dropping 1–2°C below normal. Tree-ring data show 1816 as one of the coldest years in 600 years, and ice core records preserve a massive sulfate spike. The Tambora eruption remains the benchmark for volcanic climate impacts. The VEI 7 event was roughly 10 times larger than Pinatubo 1991 (VEI 6), which caused ~0.5°C global cooling. Krakatau 1883 (VEI 6) cooled the planet by ~1.2°C. Tambora provides a critical real-world data point for modeling consequences of future large eruptions.

cultural_significance.content:
The cultural legacy of the 1815 eruption extends far beyond Indonesia. The most famous connection is the genesis of ‘Frankenstein’: in the cold, rainy summer of 1816, Mary Shelley and companions at Lake Geneva, Switzerland, were inspired by their confinement to write ghost stories. Mary Shelley’s contribution became one of the foundational works of science fiction, published in 1818. John Polidori’s ‘The Vampyre’ from the same competition launched modern vampire fiction.

The dramatic sunsets from stratospheric aerosols influenced J.M.W. Turner’s paintings. Agricultural crises contributed to social upheaval across post-Napoleonic Europe. On Sumbawa, the eruption obliterated the Kingdom of Tambora, a sultanate whose culture, language, and people were entirely destroyed — one of the few cases of volcanic eruption causing complete extinction of a political and linguistic community. Archaeological excavations at the ‘Pompeii of the East’ site have recovered artifacts from this lost civilization.

visiting_and_tourism.content:
Mount Tambora is a compelling volcanic destination, though remote compared to Bali or Java volcanoes. The primary attraction is the summit caldera. The standard ascent from Pancasila village on the southern flank gains approximately 2,300 m over 12–15 km, typically taking 2 days with an overnight camp. The caldera rim offers staggering views into the 6-km-wide, 1,250-m-deep crater.

Reaching Tambora requires flying to Bima’s Sultan Muhammad Salahuddin Airport from Bali or Lombok, then driving 3–4 hours. Local guides are essential and facilities basic. The dry season (May–October) is best for trekking. The ‘Pompeii of the East’ archaeological excavation on the northern flank is an additional attraction.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Tambora sits within the eastern Sunda Volcanic Arc. Indonesia has over 100 active Holocene volcanoes. The nearest significant neighbor is Sangeang Api, a highly active stratovolcano approximately 50 km east (last erupted 2015). Rinjani on Lombok (3,726 m), approximately 200 km west, features a scenic caldera lake. Further west lie Agung and Batur on Bali, Merapi and Kelud on Java, and Krakatau in the Sunda Strait.

etymology.content: The name ‘Tambora’ derives from the local Bima language. Its precise meaning is uncertain, though some sources suggest it may relate to an invitation or summons. The prefix ‘ta-’ in the Bima language can indicate a place or location. Before 1815, the name referred both to the mountain and to the small sultanate (Kingdom of Tambora) on its northern slopes. The Indonesian prefix ‘Gunung’ (mountain) is formally used: Gunung Tambora.

faqs.question: What happened during the 1815 eruption of Tambora?
faqs.answer: The April 1815 eruption of Mount Tambora was the largest volcanic eruption in recorded human history. After precursory activity from 1812, a major explosive phase began on April 5, 1815, with the climactic paroxysm on April 10–11. The eruption column reached approximately 43 km into the stratosphere. Pyroclastic flows swept all flanks, reaching the sea on every side. The eruption ejected approximately 150 km³ of tephra, reduced the summit from ~4,300 m to 2,850 m, and created a caldera 6 km wide and 1,250 m deep. An estimated 60,000–92,000 people died from direct effects and subsequent famine. The eruption caused the Year Without a Summer in 1816 through stratospheric sulfate aerosols.

faqs.question: What was the Year Without a Summer?
faqs.answer: The Year Without a Summer refers to 1816, when global temperatures dropped by approximately 0.4–0.7°C due to stratospheric sulfur dioxide from Tambora’s 1815 eruption. In Europe, it was the coldest summer on record, with frost and snow in June and July. Crop failures caused the last great European subsistence famine, with food riots in France, Switzerland, and Germany. In northeastern North America, frost occurred in every month. The agricultural crisis caused widespread economic hardship, accelerated westward migration in the United States, and inspired Mary Shelley to write Frankenstein during the cold, stormy summer at Lake Geneva.

faqs.question: Is Mount Tambora still active?
faqs.answer: Yes, Mount Tambora is classified as an active volcano, though it is in a long period of repose. The most recent volcanic activity occurred on July 2, 1967 — minor steam emissions from the caldera floor. The caldera hosts fumarolic vents emitting steam and volcanic gases, and seismic monitoring detects occasional volcanic earthquakes. A repeat of the 1815 VEI 7 event is considered extremely unlikely on human timescales. More plausible near-term scenarios include minor phreatic eruptions or lava dome growth within the caldera.

faqs.question: How many people died in the 1815 Tambora eruption?
faqs.answer: The total estimated death toll is approximately 60,000 to 92,000, making it the deadliest volcanic eruption in recorded history. Approximately 12,000 people were killed directly by pyroclastic flows, tephra fall, and tsunamis. The remaining 49,000–80,000 deaths occurred from famine and epidemic disease caused by widespread crop destruction across Sumbawa, Lombok, and eastern Java. The Kingdom of Tambora — a sultanate of approximately 10,000 people — was entirely wiped out. These figures do not include deaths caused globally by the Year Without a Summer famines.

faqs.question: How tall is Mount Tambora?
faqs.answer: Mount Tambora currently stands at 2,850 m (9,350 ft). Before the 1815 eruption, it reached approximately 4,300 m (14,100 ft), one of the tallest peaks in Indonesia. The eruption removed roughly 1,450 m from the summit and created a caldera 6 km wide and 1,250 m deep. This dramatic reduction — losing more than a third of its elevation in a single event — is one of the most striking geological transformations in recorded volcanic history.

faqs.question: How does Tambora compare to Krakatau?
faqs.answer: Tambora 1815 was significantly larger than Krakatau 1883. Tambora was VEI 7 vs Krakatau VEI 6 — a tenfold difference on the logarithmic scale. Tambora ejected ~150 km³ of tephra (~41 km³ DRE) vs Krakatau’s ~25 km³ (~12 km³ DRE). Tambora’s death toll (60,000–92,000) was higher than Krakatau’s (~36,000, mostly from tsunamis). Tambora’s climate impact was also more severe. Despite being larger, Tambora is less famous because the 1883 eruption occurred in the age of telegraphy and was reported globally in real-time.

faqs.question: Can you visit Mount Tambora?
faqs.answer: Yes, though Tambora is remote compared to Bali or Java volcanoes. The standard ascent from Pancasila village on the southern flank takes 2 days, gaining ~2,300 m through tropical forest to the caldera rim. Views into the 6-km-wide, 1,250-m-deep crater are staggering. Reaching the trailhead requires flying to Bima on Sumbawa (from Bali or Lombok), then driving 3–4 hours. Local guides are essential. The dry season (May–October) is best. The Pompeii of the East archaeological site on the northern flank is an additional attraction.

faqs.question: How did Tambora’s eruption create Frankenstein?
faqs.answer: The connection is indirect but well-documented. Tambora’s 1815 eruption created stratospheric aerosols that made the summer of 1816 the coldest on record in Europe. In June 1816, Mary Shelley, Percy Shelley, Lord Byron, and John Polidori were at the Villa Diodati near Lake Geneva, Switzerland. The relentless cold and rain kept them indoors, and Byron proposed a ghost-story competition. This inspired Mary Shelley to write Frankenstein (published 1818) and Polidori to write The Vampyre. The dreary weather was a direct consequence of Tambora’s eruption 12,000 km away.

faqs.question: Could the 1815 eruption happen again?
faqs.answer: A repeat VEI 7 eruption is considered extremely unlikely on human timescales but not impossible on geological ones. Such eruptions typically require thousands to tens of thousands of years to accumulate sufficient magma. Only ~210 years have passed since 1815. More plausible scenarios involve minor phreatic eruptions or lava dome growth. However, if a VEI 7 eruption occurred again — at Tambora or any volcano — it would cause a global climate crisis potentially disrupting food production for 2–3 years, with consequences far more severe than 1816 given today’s interconnected global food system.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Tambora?
faqs.answer: Mount Tambora is a stratovolcano (composite volcano) with an unusual alkalic magma composition. Its lavas are dominantly trachybasaltic to trachyandesitic, richer in alkali elements than typical Indonesian volcanoes. The massive edifice forms the entire 60-km-wide Sanggar Peninsula — an enormous volcanic structure. The 1815 eruption transformed it from a towering stratovolcano (~4,300 m) to a caldera-topped truncated cone (2,850 m), illustrating the destructive potential of large composite volcanoes above subduction zones.
